newsitem.title: GERMANY: Lufthansa cargo plans 7 pct rate rise in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Lufthansa cargo plans 7 pct rate rise in 1997.

text.p: Lufthansa Cargo AG (LCAG) said it plans two rounds of rates rises in 1997 to try to improve profitability and stop the fall in air cargo market rates.
LCAG chairman Wilhelm Althen said an early spring rise of up to seven percent would be followed by a second round of rises by September 1997.
The Deutsche Lufthansa AG cargo subsidiary raised rates to selected destinations by up to 10 percent and on certain types of goods from October 1 this year.
Althen told a Frankfurt news conference: "As the market leader we must seize the initiative. We will increase prices next year."
He added: "I think it will be about seven percent. There will be routes where we have to increase by up to 10 percent," he said.
The rates increase was likely to come into effect from March 1 and would be differentiated by routes and countries.
"There will have to be a second round of increases in the autumn, in mid-August to September," he added.
Air cargo market rates have fallen steadily in 1995 and 1996 due to over-capacity and weak demand in some markets, observers said.
Althen warned: "If we do not increase prices then this industry will not be in the position to provide capacity and we would have to quit part of the market," he warned.
Lufthansa Cargo made a loss of 66 million marks in the first three quarters of 1996 and does not expect to break even until 1998.
Althen said Lufthansa Cargo lost "a lot of business" to airlines which delayed introducing a cargo fuel surcharge until November 15.
Lufthansa Cargo added a global 10 US cents surcharge with effect from November 1, a move since followed by virtually all airlines in the freight business.
